video_caption: The video features a presentation slide with a gray background and white circuit-like patterns, indicating a technological theme. The slide is titled "Deep Learning Applications: AI in Banking," with the text highlighted in red, emphasizing the focus on artificial intelligence within the banking sector. The presenter, wearing a red shirt, appears in the bottom right corner, suggesting a live or recorded presentation. The background behind the presenter includes a floral pattern, adding a touch of color to the otherwise monochromatic slide. The slide then transitions to a new title, "AI in Banking: The Transition of legacy Banks," with the same red highlighting, indicating a shift in the presentation's focus to the adaptation of traditional banks to AI technologies. The presenter remains in the same position, maintaining continuity in the presentation. The video maintains a professional and informative atmosphere throughout, with the consistent use of visual elements to reinforce the technological and banking themes.

The video features a presentation slide titled "Types of AI Applications in Banking," dated June 17, 2020, from Business Insider Intelligence. The slide displays a bar graph comparing the usage of various AI applications by investment banks and insurers across global markets. The applications listed are Natural Language Processing, Image Analysis, Robotic Process Automation, Predictive Analysis, and Machine Learning, with corresponding percentages indicating their adoption rates. The graph shows that Natural Language Processing is the most widely used at 52%, followed by Predictive Analysis at 60%, and Machine Learning at 63%. The source of the data is cited as "The road ahead: Artificial Intelligence and the future of financial services," published by The Economist Intelligence Unit and Thoughtspot on June 2, 2020. The slide also includes a small inset image of a person, presumably the presenter, with a blurred face, wearing a green shirt, and standing in front of a background featuring a road and trees. The presenter's name and affiliation, "Digital Science Center," are visible in the bottom left corner. The video maintains a consistent focus on the slide throughout, with no significant changes in the visual elements or the presenter's position.

The video features a man wearing a red shirt and glasses, standing in front of a whiteboard with text detailing the "UK Bank Closings January 30, 2020." The text on the whiteboard explains that Lloyds Banking Group is closing an additional 56 branches in 2020 as part of cost-cutting efforts, with a total of 3,300 branch closures in the UK between January 2015 and August 2019, equivalent to 34% of the overall branch network. The man appears to be presenting or discussing the information on the whiteboard, which includes a reference to a Business Insider Intelligence article. The background is simple, with a plain wall and a digital science center logo visible in the bottom left corner. The video maintains a consistent focus on the man and the whiteboard throughout, with no significant changes in the environment or the man's actions.

The video features a man wearing a red shirt and glasses, standing in front of a large screen displaying a news article titled "UK Bank Closings January 30, 2020." The article discusses Lloyds Banking Group's announcement of additional branch closures for 2020, with a total of 56 branches expected to close by October. The text highlights the impact of these closures, which are part of the bank's cost-cutting efforts, and mentions the significant number of branch closures in the UK over the past six years. The man appears to be presenting or discussing the information on the screen, which is set in a professional environment, likely a conference room or a presentation space. The background is simple, with a focus on the screen and the presenter, emphasizing the importance of the news being shared. The video maintains a consistent visual theme throughout, with no significant changes in the scene or the presenter's actions.

The video begins with a presentation slide titled "Downsizing Physical Branches," detailing UniCredit SpA's plans to cut around 8,000 jobs and 500 branches by 2023, aiming for â‚¬1 billion in savings. The slide, marked with the date December 4, 2019, and sourced from the Wall Street Journal, includes a link to a survey and is presented by the Digital Science Center. In the top right corner, a man in a red shirt appears, seemingly engaged in delivering the presentation. The scene transitions to a new slide titled "Declining Physical Banks I," featuring two bar graphs. The first graph, labeled "UK Banks Closing The Biggest Share Of Their Branches," shows various banks and their respective branch closures between January 2015 and August 2019. The second graph, titled "Bank Of America's Branch Network," displays the number of branches from 2009 to 2019, with a declining trend. The slide is branded with the Bank of America logo and the Business Insider logo, indicating the source of the data. The man in the red shirt remains visible in the top right corner throughout the video, maintaining a consistent presence as the presenter.

The video features a man in a red shirt, seated in front of a colorful background, presenting a slide titled "Declining Physical Banks I." The slide is divided into two sections: on the left, a bar graph titled "UK Banks Closing The Biggest Share Of Their Branches" shows various banks and the percentage of branches they have closed, with RBS leading at 85%. On the right, a bar graph titled "Bank Of America's Branch Network" displays the number of branches from 2009 to 2019, showing a consistent decline. The man appears to be explaining the data, gesturing towards the graphs. The slide includes logos for Bank of America and Business Insider, and a note at the bottom states the source as "Company Filings, The Wall Street Journal, 2019." The video maintains a consistent focus on the slide and the presenter, with no significant changes in the environment or the man's actions throughout the sequence.

The video features a presentation slide titled "Declining Physical Banks II," dated January 16, 2020, from Business Insider Intelligence's Banking Pro. The slide showcases three bar graphs comparing Citibank's digital channels growth against the decline of physical banks across three metrics: Online Banking Customer Growth, Agent Contact Rate, and E-Statement Penetration. The first graph illustrates the increase in mobile and digital customers from Q4 2017 to Q4 2019, with mobile customers rising from 15.0 million to 29.4 million and digital customers from 26.4 million to 32.5 million. The second graph depicts a decrease in agent contact rate from 1.34 in Q4 2017 to 1.26 in Q4 2019, marked by a red arrow and "-4%" annotation. The third graph shows an increase in e-statement penetration from 45% in Q4 2017 to 92% in Q4 2019, with a "+7 ppts" annotation. A note at the bottom explains that agent contact rate is calculated by the total number of agent-handled calls divided by average total active accounts. The source is credited to Company filings, 2020. In the bottom left corner, a man in a red shirt appears to be presenting, with a blurred background featuring a painting. The Business Insider Intelligence logo is visible in the bottom right corner. The presentation slide remains consistent throughout the video, with no significant changes in the graphs or annotations.

The video features a man wearing a red shirt, seated in front of a computer screen displaying an article titled "AI and Size of Bank Staff," dated November 25, 2019. The article discusses Deutsche Bank's use of automation to achieve job cuts, highlighting the role of AI in increasing productivity and reducing manual work. The man appears to be reading or presenting the article, with his attention focused on the screen. The background is a simple indoor setting, with a neutral-colored wall and a hint of a window or picture frame visible. The text on the screen is clear and legible, with the article's content discussing the potential for AI to reduce staff in the banking industry and the importance of balancing automation with human touch in customer service. The man's facial expression is neutral, and he seems engaged with the material. The video maintains a consistent focus on the article and the man, with no significant changes in the environment or the man's actions throughout the sequence.

The video features a static image of a text article titled "Making the g Transition? Not everybody will," discussing the financial performance and challenges faced by Goldman Sachs in comparison to its competitors. The article highlights Goldman Sachs' past success, its current struggles, and the impact of tighter regulations and technological advancements on the banking industry. The text is accompanied by a small image of two individuals in business attire, one of whom is wearing a red tie, situated in the bottom right corner. The background is white, and the text is presented in a clear, readable font. The article is sourced from the Digital Credit Suisse, as indicated by the logo in the bottom left corner. Throughout the video, there are no visible changes or movements, maintaining a consistent focus on the article's content and layout.

The video features a man seated in front of a computer screen, wearing a red shirt and glasses, with his hands clasped together. He appears to be engaged in a discussion or presentation, as indicated by his focused expression and the presence of a microphone clipped to his shirt. The background is a plain, light-colored wall, and the setting suggests an indoor environment, possibly an office or a conference room. The text on the screen reads, "FINTECH WORKFORCE TO GROW BY 19% IN NEXT DECADE DUE TO AI While incumbents expect AI to reduce their headcount by 9%," highlighting the impact of artificial intelligence on the financial technology sector. The text is presented in a clear, bold font, making it easily readable against the light background. The man's posture and the setup suggest that he is delivering information or insights related to the topic displayed on the screen. The overall atmosphere is professional and focused, with the man's attire and the content of the text reinforcing the theme of technology and finance.

The video features a man seated in front of a computer screen, engaged in reading or presenting a document. The document, titled "FINTECH WORKFORCE TO GROW BY 19% IN NEXT DECADE DUE TO AI," discusses the impact of artificial intelligence on the financial services industry, particularly on incumbents and fintechs. The man, dressed in a red shirt, appears focused and attentive, with his gaze directed towards the screen. The background is simple and uncluttered, emphasizing the content on the screen. The text on the screen is in English, with key phrases highlighted in blue, such as "incumbents and fintechs," indicating a focus on these terms. The document outlines the expected growth in the fintech workforce due to AI, with a specific mention of a 19% increase over the next decade. The man's posture and the setting suggest a professional or educational context, possibly a seminar or a study session. The video maintains a consistent focus on the man and the document, with no significant changes in the environment or the man's actions throughout the sequence.

The video features a presentation slide titled "Jobs Impact of AI in Banking," dated February 11, 2020, from Business Insider Intelligence FINTECH PRO. The slide displays a bar graph comparing the expected AI-induced net job changes from 2019 to 2030 for incumbents and fintechs. The graph shows a decline in job changes for incumbents, with a 3% decrease in 2022, a 2% decrease in 2025, and a 9% decrease in 2030. Conversely, fintechs are projected to see a 10% increase in 2025 and a 19% increase in 2030. The source of the data is cited as the Cambridge Centre for Alternative Finance, with a sample size of 805 respondents. The slide is presented by a person wearing a red shirt, seated in front of a floral-patterned background. The video maintains a consistent focus on the slide and the presenter, with no significant changes in the environment or the presenter's actions throughout the sequence.
